review.title: Second International Nurse Rostering Competition (INRC-II) --- Problem Description and Rules ---
review.abstract: In this paper, we provide all information to participate to the Second International Nurse Rostering Competition (INRC-II). First, we describe the problem formulation, which, differently from INRC-I, is a multi-stage procedure. Second, we illustrate all the necessary infrastructure do be used together with the participant's solver, including the testbed, the file formats, and the validation/simulation tools. Finally, we state the rules of the competition. All update-to-date information about the competition is available at

sections.heading: 1 Introduction

sections.heading: 2 Problem definition
sections.text: The basic (one-tier) problem is the weekly division of a fixed number of nurses into shifts, so that a nurse works one shift or has one day off each day. Nurses can have several skills, and for each skill we get different coverage requirements. Given the multi-stage nature of the overall process, the input data for the problem comes from three different sources, the so-called scenarios, week dates and history, as explained in the following sections. Appendix A. The way the information in the files is organized.

sections.heading: 2.1 Scenario
sections.text: The scenario presents the general data common to all phases of the overall process. It contains the following information: Planning horizon: The number of weeks that make up the planning period. Skills: The list of skills involved in the problem (chief nurse, regular nurse, trainee,...). Each nurse has one or more skills, but each shift covers exactly one qualification requirement. Contracts: Each nurse has a specific contract (full-time, part-time, on-call,...). The contract sets limits on the distribution and number of tasks within the planning horizon. In detail, it includes: • minimum and maximum total number of tasks within the planning horizon; • minimum and maximum number of consecutive days off; • maximum number of working weeks within the planning horizon; • a Boolean value representing the presence of the full weekend limit for the nurse, stating that the nurse should work on both days of the week.

sections.heading: 2.2 Week data
sections.text: The weekly data contain the specific data for each week. It consists of the following information: Requirements: For each shift, for each skill, for each day of the week, the optimum and minimum number of nurses necessary to perform the work tasks is given. Nurse requests: A series of three requests is given, each consisting of the name of the nurse, the day of the week and a shift. The presence of a given triple request represents the request of the nurse not to work on the given shift on the given day. The special shift name Any represents the request not to work on any shift of the day, i.e. to have a day off. The above information varies from week to week due to the variability of the number of current patients and specific preferences of the nurses. Normally, every week starts with Monday, so that the data is stored in the order Mo, Di,..., Sun.

sections.heading: 2.3 History
sections.text: The story contains the information that must be transferred from one week to the next in order to evaluate the restrictions correctly. Specifically, for each nurse, the following two types of information are given: Limit data: The limit data is used to verify the restrictions on consecutive assignments: • Shift work on the last day of the previous week or the special value None if the nurse had a day off; • Number of consecutive shifts of the same type and number of consecutive shifts in general (both are 0 if the last shift is none); • Number of consecutive days off (0 if the last shift is none). Counters: The counters collect the cumulative value over the weeks of certain interest variables that need to be verified only at the end of the planning period. These are: • Total number of shifts performed; • Total number of weekends performed. The story is computed after each week based on the solution provided by the solver and based on the previous story. The values that the story may have on the first week passed to the solder during the first week.

sections.heading: 2.4 Solution
sections.text: The complete solving process is a loop that performs the solver for a week at each step, iterating for all weeks during the planning period (4 or 8 weeks). After each week, the history information is calculated based on the solution and the previous story and provided in a new file. This is done through the provided simulator, while the solver only has to provide the solution itself. The complete process is outlined in Figure 1 (a), assuming a scenario of 4 weeks. Input files are colored in different cyan shades and the output files in different shades on Magenta. In addition to generating a solution file after solving each stage, the solver may want to store some more prediction information in a custom file (in yellow in Figure 1) and pass it on to the next solution call to better guide the solution of the next step. The content and format of this file is free, but its name is specified by the nurse, which is specified in the 1.section of the output for the nurses, which is produced on Tuesday.

sections.heading: 2.5 Constraints
sections.text: According to the setting outlined above, we divide the constraints into two groups: those that can be calculated separately for each week, and those that are only calculated globally at the end of the planning period. As usual, they are also divided into hard and soft constraints. The former must always be met, and the latter contribute to the objective function. The weight of each individual soft constraint is shown before its subsequent description.

sections.heading: 2.5.1 Constraints on the single week
sections.text: Below is the list of hard (H) and soft (S) limitation types: H1. Single assignment per day: A nurse may be assigned a maximum of one shift per day.H2. Understaffing: The number of nurses required for each shift must be at least the minimum requirement.H3. Shift assignment: The shift assignment of a nurse for two consecutive days must be one of the legal successions envisaged in the scenario.H4. Lack of required skills: A shift of a given skill must necessarily be performed by a nurse with that skill. S1. Insufficient staffing for optimal coverage (30): The number of nurses required per shift must be the optimal requirement.H4. Any nurse lacking skills will be punished according to the weight provided. Additional nurses above the optimum value will not be factored into the costs.S2. Successive assignments (15 / 30): Minimum and maximum number of consecutive tasks per shift, per shift, or globally, or the respective weight, should include the corresponding assessment or the appropriate weight.4.

sections.heading: 2.5.2 Constraints spanning over the planning horizon
sections.text: The following (soft) restrictions will only be assessed at the end of the planning period: S6. Total orders (20): For each nurse, the total number of assignments (working days) must be within the limits (minimum and maximum) enforced by her contract. The difference (in each direction), multiplied by her weight, will be added to the objective function.S7 Total work weekends (30): For each nurse, the number of working weekends must be less or equal to the maximum. The number of overworked weekends will be multiplied by the objective function. A weekend is considered "working" if at least one of the two days (Saturday and Sunday) is occupied by the nurse. Of course, the solver should take into account the restrictions S6 and S7 in each individual phase. However, their injury values show a decreasing degree of uncertainty that shifts from one week to the next, and only in the last week can they be assessed accurately. It is up to the model to decide the costs in the previous phase.

sections.heading: 3 Instances
sections.text: A complete solution process requires entering a scenario, an initial history, and 4 (or 8) weeks data, and it produces 4 (or 8) weeks solutions and a final history. Scenario, week data, history, and weekly solutions are written in separate files, each with its own syntax. For easy processing, all files are provided in XML, JSON, and text-only formats, and each participant can use the format he / she deems most convenient for his / her implementation. File formats are grouped in Appendix A. Files belonging to the same case are grouped into a data set consisting of the following data sets: • 1 scenario file; • 3 initial history files; • 10 weeks data files. An instance is thus a specific scenario, an initial history, and a sequence of 4 (or 8) weeks records, all belonging to the same data set. The same data collection may also be used several times in the same instance.

sections.heading: 4 Tools
sections.text: We provide participants with a range of software tools. The simulator manages the multi-step solution process. The validator certifies the quality of a given instance. The executable benchmark calculates the permitted runtime for each computer. Finally, the feasibility checker gives the participant the opportunity to check whether a particular instance of a given data set has at least one solution that meets all the tough constraints or not.

sections.heading: 4.1 Simulator
sections.text: The competition website supports the Java Simulator.jar program, which performs the simulation > and delivers the cost. As shown in Figure 1, the simulator receives a scenario file, an initial history file, the executable filename of the solver, and a sequence of week files as its input. It then applies the solver to each data file described above and generates a history file for each level based on the solution called by each solver. After the last week, the data file is resolved in the sequence, the validator is called to evaluate the entire planning horizon. In addition to the basic input described above, the user can also specify random seeds for his solver, the directory in which the solver is executed, and the directory in which all solution files, generated history files, log files (the console is evaluated after each call).

sections.heading: 4.2 Validator
sections.text: The validator is a Java program that verifies the validity of a solution of an instance and calculates the corresponding objective functional value using the evaluation method (see also Annex B) and the limitations described in Section 2.4. sections.heading: 4.3 Benchmark
sections.text: For each problem size defined as the number of nurses in the scenario file, the program tells you how long you can run your algorithm for each level. It is not possible to provide perfectly fair benchmarks for many platforms and algorithms, and we know that the benchmark may be friendlier to some people than to others. It is noted that all finalists are run on a standard machine, creating a level playing field. It is only suitable for single processor machines, for example, it is not suitable for specialized parallel machines or clusters. Generally, it is allowed for multi-core machines to use a single core for the competition.The benchmark is provided as executable for different architectures. If your architecture is not among those provided, please contact us to obtain the program. The program should be run if the machine is not used for anything else.

sections.heading: 4.4 Feasibility Checker
sections.text: It may be that an instance created from a given data set is unworkable. To prevent participants from wasting time searching for workable solutions when they do not exist, a Feasibility Check is provided. This tool is a web service and will be available on the competition website as of November 5, 2014.

sections.heading: 5 Competition rules
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.1 General rules
sections.text: In fact, most of them will be able to play by the rules they have established in the past.

sections.heading: 5.2 Dates
sections.text: The competition will start on October 17, 2014. On that day, we will publish the data sets, this specification, the simulator, the validator and the benchmark program. The web service for the feasibility assessor will be available on November 5, 2014. On May 15, 2015, the late data, i.e. a list of specific entities created from the competition test bed, will be published. The deadline for submitting the best results of the participants and their solvers is June 1, 2015. Notifications of the finalists will be sent out on July 1, 2015. Winners will be announced at the MISTA 2015 conference in Prague (August 25-27, 2015).

sections.heading: 5.3 Adjudication procedure
sections.text: We follow the same scoring procedure of INRC-I [8], of which the lowest score was imported from the Second International Scheduling Competition (ITC-2007) [10]. It is repeated here for the benefit of Participant i, for example. In the case of Participant i, an unworkable solution is offered, for example, j or he / she does not provide it at all, Xij is assigned a conventional value M, which is greater than all results delivered (and verified) by the other Participants for that instance. Matrix X of results is transformed into a matrix of ranks R, which assigns each Rij a value from 1 to k, and Xij is assigned a conventional value M, which is supplied by the other Participants for that instance.

sections.heading: 5.4 Prizes
sections.text: The three first-place finishers share e 1729 among themselves (first prize e 819, second prize e 637, third prize e 273) and receive a free registration for PATAT 2016, which also includes a special race track.

sections.heading: A File formats
sections.text: In this appendix we describe the format of the input files (scenario, week data and history) and the output file (solution). Since XML and JSON files have the same structure but are more self-explanatory, only the text-only format is explained in detail.

sections.text: The first line of the scenario file contains the name of the dataset in nXXXwY format, where XXX is the number of nurses and Y is the number of weeks of the planning horizon. This is the identifier of the scenario, which is then used in the corresponding history, week and solution files.

sections.heading: B Constraint evaluation
sections.text: In this appendix, we explain some of the limitations set forth in Section 2.5 in more detail. In particular, we believe that the limitations relating to limit data (history file) require a deeper explanation. Conversely, the limitations H1, H2, S1, S4, S5, S6, and S7 do not rely on limit data for their evaluation, and in our opinion their evaluation is simple and not subject to ambiguous interpretation. For the remaining limitations, we describe their evaluation exhaustively at both limits of a level. In the following descriptions, for simplicity reasons, we disregard the weight of the (soft) restrictions and focus on the extent of the violation. For convenience, we assume that the input data is included in the following fragment of a scenario file that sets all restrictions to the same value 3.
